title: Re: SGA in a SUPERBOWL commercial? Edit: (almost)
content:
Those are really katakana characters that can be written as "tookutsu".

Katakana are mostly used for loan words like video (japanese bideo), radio (rajio), password (pasuwaado) etc. and they mostly mean something that is close to the original word, but there can be differences. Sometimes they are from spanish, french, german etc. but mostly from english.
Another use for katakana is company names that doesn't mean a thing. I guess this one is like that.
The matrix had katakana characters and numbers but flipped.

I attended japanese classes for a year, so...

PS. I guess you didn't really want to know all these [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]

*edit* it can be "toowatsu" too, "wa" and "ka" are similar and depends on the font face how they look. Could it mean "towards"? You couldn't find either in dictionaries though.
Look at [img]http://www5.big.or.jp/~otake/hey/kanji/gifmoji/katakana.gif[/img], if you want to know more![hr]The human brain is not user-friendly...

title: Re: *enlightened*
content:
SGA 'n' is almost certainly borrowed from the katakana 'n' (though it could also be 'so', as the only difference is the angle of a line and SGA leaves that line ambiguous). SGA 'o' bears a resemblance to a lot of kana forms, too.

'b' looks a lot like the Japanese/Chinese/Korean character read as 'ko' in Japanese, only upside down. But it also looks a lot like a lowercase 'b', so that's probably a coincidence.

(I work as a Japanese interpreter, lol)

'e' and 'm' look to me like they might be alluding to the simple "pigpen cipher", which was used in the American Revolutionary War (God knows why, though; it's a simplistic substitution cipher) and is now frequently employed by grade school kids.

[quote]Quote:[hr]Aah. I always wondered about the origin of those characters. Strange how everyone seems to think they're latin letters...[hr][/quote]

Ha, that's pretty dumb, considering that what we are writing in right now are Latin characters.

[quote]Quote:[hr]and I noticed that all the drawings of post-boxes (the things that you post your letters into, not the ones that you get your letters delivered to) had the symbol of the SGA letter "H".[hr][/quote]

Yeah, that's "yuubin maaku" -- mail mark. [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yubin_mark]It prefixes postal codes in Japan, and also serves as a universal shorthand symbol for "mail".[/url]

irrelevant P.S.: And "manga" refers exclusively to Japanese "graphic novel"-type comics, but people will apply it to anything that looks like a drawing and holds still long enough, because the current fad is to completely fail to ever shut up about Japan, ever.
